Award.AwardTitle: Completing the WAIS Divide Ice Core CO2 record
Award.AbstractNarration:
Brook/1246465

This award supports a project to measure the carbon dioxide (CO2) concentration in the WAIS Divide ice core covering the time period 25,000 to 60,000 years before present, and to analyze the isotopic composition of CO2 in selected time intervals. The research will improve understanding of how and why atmospheric CO2 varied during the last ice age, focusing particularly on abrupt transitions in the concentration record that are associated with abrupt climate change. These events represents large perturbations to the global climate system and better information about the CO2 response should inform our understanding of carbon cycle-climate feedbacks and radiative forcing of climate. The research will also improve analytical methods in support of these goals, including completing development of sublimation methods to replace laborious mechanical crushing of ice to release air for analysis. The intellectual merit of the proposed work is that it will increase knowledge about the magnitude and timing of atmospheric CO2 variations during the last ice age, and their relationship to regional climate in Antarctica, global climate history, and the history of abrupt climate change in the Northern Hemisphere. The temporal resolution of the proposed record will in most intervals be ~ 4 x higher than previous data sets for this time period, and for selected intervals up to 8-10 times higher. Broader impacts of the proposed work include a significant addition to the amount of data documenting the history of the most important long-lived greenhouse gas in the atmosphere and more information about carbon cycle-climate feedbacks - important parameters for predicting future climate change. The project will contribute to training a postdoctoral researcher, research experience for an undergraduate and a high school student, and outreach to local middle school and other students. It will also improve the analytical infrastructure at OSU, which will be available for future projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project created a very complete record of the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere for the period from 68,000 years to present.  The data are significantly more detailed than any other analagous record and answer several important questions about the history of carbon dioxide and its relationship to climate change.  First, they resolve the question of the timing of carbon dioxide with respect to temperature changes in Antarctica at the end of the last ice age. The uncertainty of this timing has been a major issue for interpreting cause and effect in the ice core record for non-specialists and the media. Previous data suggested that carbon dioxide changed after temperature, leading some to conclude that carbon dioxide was not involved in the temperature change.  This conclusion was erroneous because carbon dioxide is a major feedback on natural climate change, and amplifies past warming caused by changes in the earth's orbit.  The confusion was still an important issue.  Because the age of the gas in the WAIS Divide core is very accurately known it is now possible to clearly state what the timing of carbon dioxide and Antarctic temperature change is at the end of the last ice age.   In brief, there is no discernible, significant lead or lag of carbon dioxide with respect to Antarctic temperature change between 18,000 and 10,000 years ago, they change together, and our most recent work extends this back to 68,000 years.   Furthermore, we can confirm that carbon dioxide lags global temperature. This is an important conclusion because it shows how interlinked carbon dioxide  and climate are in the natural earth system.

Second, the data clearly reveal that atmospheric carbon dioxide levels changed abruptly numerous times during the period of study.   During these events carbon dioxide levels rose ~ 10 ppm in a century or two. We document a link between changes in carbon dioxide  and both warming in the northern hemisphere and shifts in atmospheric and ocean circulation associated with cooling in the northern hemisphere.

Third, the extremely detailed data from WAIS Divide show that carbon dioxide concentrations  did not experience major "overshoots" at abrupt events,a possibility that had been raised in earlier work in the context of large emissions of carbon dioxide from Arctic permafrost thaw. This is important because of concerns about Arctic carbon budgets in the future.
